awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Machine learning blueprints for greener chelants
awd_abstract_narration:
1705592 (Keith). Chelating agents have recently been identified as a key category of chemical products that are ripe for greener design. It is hypothesized that identifying better alternatives will require far broader explorations of chemical compound space than what is possible with conventional trial and error experimentation. In this project, accurate quantum chemistry calculations will be used to train state-of-the-art machine learning methods that will allow prediction of structures of greener chelating agents.

The machine learning method that will be developed promises a novel route to rapidly predict properties of chelant/metal complexes, not only with higher accuracy but with six orders of magnitude less computational time than conventional predictive quantum chemistry methods (e.g. Kohn-Sham Density Functional Theory). With this computational tool, it will be possible to rapidly screen through about 100,000 hypothetical chelant structures to predict those that would bind strongly to different metal ions. The project will also screen these complexes to see which have high propensities to degrade in reasonable timeframes, and which have low probabilities of being toxic. The top candidates from this novel screening approach will then be experimentally synthesized and tested. This will validate if quantum chemistry-based machine learning would be a transformative tool for environmental sustainability and green chemical design by being a more predictive supplement and/or alternative to conventional QSAR models. Four basic scientific questions will be addressed by the project. First, state-of-the-art computational quantum chemistry will be used to develop a quantitative understanding of which chelant/metal complex properties (bond energies, pKas, etc.) best correlate with overall chelant stability constants in aqueous solutions. Second, machine learning methods will be developed to be used to drive in silico searches for non-traditional molecular structures that would be able to bind as strong (or stronger) to different metal ions as EDTA. Third, additional computational screening procedures will then be used to find which of these promising chelant structures are unlikely to be non-toxic and nonpersistent in nature. Finally, it will be experimentally validated which of the novel chelants identified via computation would be industrially synthesized and economically viable for widespread use. If successful, this research effort would signify a paradigm shift for computer-aided design of greener chelants used in detergents, treatments of heavy metal poisoning, metal extraction for soil treatments, waste remediation, sequestering normally occurring radioactive materials from hydraulic fracturing sites, and water purification. This project will lay important foundational work that is needed to introduce new state-of-the-art computational modeling tools with greater predictive capacity than widely used QSAR models. All developed computer programs and accompanying tutorials for how to use the programs will be made freely available on the website of the PI. The educational component of this project will develop a computer game, "Chelate-it", which will allow students to quantify different fundamental chemical bonding concepts involved in chelation and then use that knowledge to design novel chelant structures on their own. The computer game will be tested in a summer school program at the University of Pittsburgh for underrepresented 10th grade students. The capacity for the computer game to educate students about chemical bonding, environmental sustainability engineering, and research will be assessed.

por.por_cntn:
This project was focused on research on how to best implement computational chemistry (CompChem) modeling and machine learning (ML) to guide the experimental design of new molecular chelants that would be effective and have less of an environmental footprint as existing and industrially produced ones. 


The first step toward achieving this goal was achieved by demonstrating how CompChem modeling based on accurate quantum mechanics could be used for accurately predicting solvation energies for metal ions. This is a significant challenge since accurately predicting solvation energies is a critical component of understanding structure and activity relationships of molecules in solvents. A key insight that our work found was that the energetic contributions due to local atomic scale environments in many cases can be adequately modeled by using roughly equally imperfect models of both a) a reasonably large solvent cluster and b) a solute that is surrounded by the same number of solvent molecules as was used in the cluster. We were not the first to report this modeling scheme that resulted in significant error cancelation and accurate predictive results, but we were the first to: 


1) provide a fundamental chemical physics basis for why this scheme was quantitatively accurate in relation to other known modeling schemes, 

2) demonstrate an automatable computational procedure that used a suite of several open-source codes to predict solvation energies of arbitrary ions in arbitrary solvents, and 

3) show how unsupervised ML procedures could identify how local solvent environments were progressively more converged around the ion as the number of solvent molecules in the system increased. 


These results and insights helped our group report the first computational study that predicted reasonably accurate quantitative metal-ligand stability constants for a range of metals binding to a chemical macrocycle (i.e. a cryptand molecule). A key component to accurately modeling these thermodynamic energies was the identification of a local solvent environment and accounting for the thermodynamics of acid-base chemistry on the molecule in solution. 


For this project we have also studied how local solvating environments can impact chemical reactions involving charge migrations of ions, and we have written review articles to inform the scientific community about productive and insightful applications of CompChem and ML. In sum, this project has provided important guidelines for future work in computer-aided molecular screening for properties of molecules in solvents. From this work, future efforts can turn to productively developing data sets for ML models to efficiently screen chemical space for strong candidates that warrant experimental validation. In sum, this project provided insights for how to improve the overall efficiency of identifying novel chelating agents.


As a final component for our project, we have developed a website plug-in repository that allows the scientific community and the general public to contribute and use codes that augment the open source CompChem visualization code called Avogadro, which is developed at the University of Pittsburgh.  This repository brings significant broader impacts by facilitating collaborations from around the world to make the Avogadro code even more useful for educational and research applications for current and future STEM workforces.
